intro: Cinchona gratissima, commonly known as the "Peruvian bark" or "Quina quina," is a species of tree native to the Andean regions of South America. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its evergreen foliage and yellowish-white flowers. The plant is renowned for its bark, which contains alkaloids such as quinine, historically used in the treatment of malaria. Cinchona gratissima typically grows to a height of 10–15 meters and thrives in humid, tropical climates with well-drained soil. Its ecological importance lies in its role as a source of medicinal compounds and its contribution to biodiversity in its native habitat.
